overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students analyze quadratic equations to reveal different characteristics of their graphs. They learn that a table of values represents a quadratic function when its second differences are constant. Students identify concavity, the axis of symmetry, and vertex for graphs using the equations in each form. They determine intercepts along with intervals of increase and decrease.

overview_item_data_items: I can determine and describe key features of a quadratic function and use them to solve problems.
I can identify the factored form and general form of an equation for a quadratic function and use them to highlight key features.
I can determine and interpret the average rate of change of a quadratic function over a given interval.
I can determine the equation for the axis of symmetry of a quadratic function, given the equation in general form or factored form.
A table of values representing a quadratic function has constant second differences.

It is possible to write a quadratic function in general form, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, and in factored form, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.

When the <math><mi>a</mi></math>-value of a quadratic function is positive, the graph opens upward and has an absolute minimum point. When the leading coefficient is negative, the graph opens downward and has an absolute maximum point.

The vertex of a parabola lies on its axis of symmetry. You can determine the axis of symmetry using <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> from general form.

In factored form, the values of <math><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and <math><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> are the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-intercepts of the function. In general form, <math><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is the <math><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students review what they notice about representations of a quadratic situation and the relationship between them
Students use equations and tables to identify first and second differences, then graph each function.
Students use the sign of the leading coefficient to determine whether the quadratic function has an absolute maximum or minimum.
Students investigate the connection between the axis of symmetry and the absolute minimum or maximum point.
Students write quadratic functions in factored form given their zeros and the direction in which they open.
Students generalize their process for determining characteristics of the graph for a quadratic function.

overview_item_data_items: To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
